{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3080315,"name":"","username":"Alex6940","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/47e85d/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-09-04T14:16:52.390Z","cooked":"

Since motors on turret have to spin with the turret, their wires need to be long and without fixed. But how to make sure the wires are tidy and safe in order to let turret turn at least from -180 degree to 180 degree.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-09-04T14:16:52.390Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":221,"reads":245,"readers_count":244,"score":1154.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":414724,"topic_slug":"how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52324,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret/414724/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3080319,"name":"Mykah","username":"ExploitSage","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png","created_at":"2022-09-04T14:37:00.137Z","cooked":"

The most common way I‚Äôve seen is to use a Cable Chain, Wire Loom, or similar to bundle and protect the wires.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-09-04T14:40:06.804Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":245,"readers_count":244,"score":64.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":414724,"topic_slug":"how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret","display_username":"Mykah","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16897,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"She/Her üè≥Ô∏è‚Äç‚ößÔ∏è | 9153 | Programming and Electrical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret/414724/2","custom_user_title":"She/Her üè≥Ô∏è‚Äç‚ößÔ∏è | 9153 | Programming and Electrical Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3080320,"name":"","username":"Alex6940","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/47e85d/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-09-04T14:42:30.539Z","cooked":"

But the wires will swing when the robot is moving in the court

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-09-04T14:42:30.539Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":239,"readers_count":238,"score":57.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":414724,"topic_slug":"how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":16897,"username":"ExploitSage","name":"Mykah","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52324,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret/414724/3","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3080322,"name":"Mykah","username":"ExploitSage","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png","created_at":"2022-09-04T14:44:27.902Z","cooked":"

Correct. You make the Chain/Loom long enough to move with it.

3468 has never made a proper turret, so I don‚Äôt have any pictures from our robots, but here is an example from a recent video that shows their Wire Loom

and here you can see how 118 has a Cable Chain running along a track for their turret!

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-09-04T14:53:44.458Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":222,"readers_count":221,"score":69.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":414724,"topic_slug":"how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret","display_username":"Mykah","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/uploads/default/original/3X/5/8/5808775c9dff57afa475fbe0b8518a81fffff3dc.jpeg","internal":true,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16897,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"She/Her üè≥Ô∏è‚Äç‚ößÔ∏è | 9153 | Programming and Electrical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret/414724/7","custom_user_title":"She/Her üè≥Ô∏è‚Äç‚ößÔ∏è | 9153 | Programming and Electrical Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3080327,"name":"Gus B","username":"Beanbean1706","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beanbean1706/{size}/226316_2.png","created_at":"2022-09-04T14:56:54.969Z","cooked":"

We (1706) use some black plastic stuff that we can put the cables into, then wrap tape around it. We have it automatically retract with a constant force spring. I‚Äôll send some pictures here on Monday when I head up to our shop. For now, I have a discord attachment link (won‚Äôt let me send MP4 file) showing it in action.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-09-04T14:56:54.969Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":29,"reads":215,"readers_count":214,"score":258.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":414724,"topic_slug":"how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret","display_username":"Gus B","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://media.discordapp.net/attachments/954780451833270396/991880463293624432/20220629_193144.mp4","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52632,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 1706 Build/CAD Alum"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret/414724/8","custom_user_title":"FRC 1706 Build/CAD Alum","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3080328,"name":"","username":"Alex6940","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/47e85d/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-09-04T14:57:42.571Z","cooked":"

Thank you, I will try it later.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-09-04T14:57:42.571Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":201,"readers_count":200,"score":60.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":414724,"topic_slug":"how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":16897,"username":"ExploitSage","name":"Mykah","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52324,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret/414724/9","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3080329,"name":"Mykah","username":"ExploitSage","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/exploitsage/{size}/179189_2.png","created_at":"2022-09-04T15:00:55.047Z","cooked":"
Beanbean1706:

black plastic stuff that we can put the cables into

That would be corrugated wire loom (often also called Split Loom, though not all corrugated loom is split). More durable than the fabric mesh wire loom, but less flexible, could be preferable in a case you had a LOT of cables, or thicker cables, to run from your turret.

I really like the ‚Äúcompartment‚Äù y‚Äôall created to house the excess loom!

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-09-04T15:03:49.147Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":194,"readers_count":193,"score":73.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":414724,"topic_slug":"how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret","display_username":"Mykah","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16897,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"She/Her üè≥Ô∏è‚Äç‚ößÔ∏è | 9153 | Programming and Electrical Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret/414724/10","custom_user_title":"She/Her üè≥Ô∏è‚Äç‚ößÔ∏è | 9153 | Programming and Electrical Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3080331,"name":"","username":"Alex6940","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/47e85d/{size}.png","created_at":"2022-09-04T15:02:23.528Z","cooked":"

Thanks for your help, I‚Äôll wait until Monday.

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-09-04T15:02:23.528Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":179,"readers_count":178,"score":40.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":414724,"topic_slug":"how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":52632,"username":"Beanbean1706","name":"Gus B","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/beanbean1706/{size}/226316_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":52324,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret/414724/11","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3080334,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2022-09-04T15:08:02.301Z","cooked":"
Alex6940:

how to make sure the wires are tidy and safe

Sorry I have no pictures readily available but we put the wiring harness more inside the robot than in the video posted above. You can‚Äôt see our wires and they won‚Äôt get snagged by external forces and game pieces. With the wiring ‚Äúinside,‚Äù actually better described as spiraling around and down from the turret, we have complete control of their placement and they are constrained by other robot components and partially by a curvy plastic shield around them so by carefully moving the turret slowly and testing how the wiring lays safely you can make adjustments to their placement.

Also, depending on how you want to aim, you might not need +180 to -180 rotation and maybe not even anywhere near that much. Reducing the rotation range greatly eases the cable routing problem.

Using the thinnest legal wire gauge and (expensive) most flexible insulation can help.

There are rotating connectors but we have never had to resort to those so we have no experience in how well they work for the various different signal and power circuits. Might be fun to experiment with them.

edit: I made it sound like flexible is always best and rigidity is always bad. That‚Äôs not true. You might want a rigid bundle that feds well into your chosen location instead of a limp cable that collapses in unpredictable ways. It all depends! Pick a design for the routing layout and see what the ‚Äújust right‚Äù flexibility/rigidity of the bundle is. Maybe flexible wires in a more rigid casing works best for you. On my team‚Äôs turret we tend to have a lot of wire that‚Äôs really stiff as a bundle thus the use of fabric since we don‚Äôt need more stiff to push in the right direction. And don‚Äôt forget you don‚Äôt have to have just one bundle; you can have two or more smaller bundles.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":16,"updated_at":"2022-09-04T16:29:43.309Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":187,"readers_count":186,"score":57.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":414724,"topic_slug":"how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/how-to-arrange-the-wires-on-turret/414724/12","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3080335,"name":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/slab-mr.thomas/{size}/182153_2.png","created_at":"2022-09-04T15:14:52.886Z","cooked":"
ExploitSage:

fabric mesh wire loom

My team tends to use this fabric more than more rigid tubing or channels and notice that there are more or less rigid channels depending on your need. The less rigid ones are pricey but nicely snakier.

WestCoast Products

Cable Carriers

Energy chain is the industry standard for cable management, especially when it comes to moving systems. WCP carries both single direction and bi directional energy chain useful for both elevators and turrets. 

Price: USD 14.99

Here‚Äôs some very neat turret wiring from Team 359 Hawaiian Kids at Port Hueneme Regional in 2022. They were finalists (and later regional winners), so it must have worked fairly well. frc359

67E75C4E-3EB7-4FA4-B7D2-CE3AB7CFA0D2_1_105_c1024√ó768 235 KB

Tip: If you‚Äôre building a bundle like this, include some spare wires so that you can replace a few broken wires without having to redo the harness.

bovlb:

without having to redo the harness

And no connectors or splices in the bundle!

If you want to experience maximum pain in wiring a robot, just before the first competition discover that a spool of CCA wire had been accidentally purchased and was left on a work bench and a student used it to wire the entire turret. The photo makes it look somewhat easy to change but our robot was jammed full with no nice layout like the photo. It seemed impossible to redo but it had to be done.
